docs.text:
Penkridge STEM Club


Penkridge STEM Club currently runs as an afterschool club at Marshbrook First School and is registered with 
Codeclub UK
. The club promotes the learning of STEM subjects.




STEM stands for Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths. So where do you start?


Learn


There are plenty of free resources available to help you learn about STEM subjects. Here are some of our favourites.




Hour of code


Tinkercad




Volunteer


We'd like to see all the children of Penkridge have the opportunity to find which aspects of STEM learning they enjoy the most. If you can spend an hour a week to help children learn and enjoy STEM activities please get in touch, or contact one of the following organistations:




STEMNET


Codeclub
docs.title: Home

If you can spend an hour a week to help children learn and enjoy STEM activities please get in touch, or contact one of the following organistations:   STEMNET  Codeclub

docs.text:
Hour of code


The 
hour of code
 is a hub for numerous games and projects centred on learning programming. The choice of tutorials is hugely varied and there are options available for all ages, abilities and programming languages.


Get started here: 
https://code.org/learn
docs.title: Hour of code

docs.text: The  hour of code  is a hub for numerous games and projects centred on learning programming. The choice of tutorials is hugely varied and there are options available for all ages, abilities and programming languages.  Get started here:  https://code.org/learn
docs.title: Hour of code

docs.text:
Tinkercad


Tinkercad
 is a computer program used to create 3D models for computer games or printing.




Learn


The following tutorials will help you learn how to use 
Tinkercad
.




Open 
Tinkercad
 and 
sign up
 for an account.


Open 
Tinkercad
 and 
sign in




Beginner tutorials




Create a house


Create a keyring




Intermediate Tutorials




Create a car


Create a minion




How-to




Add shapes


Add text


Align shapes


Change font


Copy and paste


Group shapes


Move shapes


Move workplane


Rotate and pan


Resize shapes


Select shapes


Zoom in / out
docs.title: Tinkercad

docs.text: Tinkercad  is a computer program used to create 3D models for computer games or printing.
docs.title: Tinkercad

docs.text: The following tutorials will help you learn how to use  Tinkercad .   Open  Tinkercad  and  sign up  for an account.  Open  Tinkercad  and  sign in
docs.title: Learn

docs.text: Create a house  Create a keyring
docs.title: Beginner tutorials

docs.text: Create a car  Create a minion
docs.title: Intermediate Tutorials

docs.text: Add shapes  Add text  Align shapes  Change font  Copy and paste  Group shapes  Move shapes  Move workplane  Rotate and pan  Resize shapes  Select shapes  Zoom in / out
docs.title: How-to

docs.text:
Register and login


Sign-up


To use TinkerCad you have to have a login.  To register for Tinkercad:




Open the 
TinkerCad
 website.


Click on the 
Sign up
 button at the top right of the website.


...




Sign-in


When you have registered you can login to Tinkercad:




Open the 
TinkerCad
 website.


Click the 
Login
 link at the top right of the website.


Enter your 
username
 and 
password
.


Click the 
Login
 button.
docs.title: Register / login

docs.text: To use TinkerCad you have to have a login.  To register for Tinkercad:   Open the  TinkerCad  website.  Click on the  Sign up  button at the top right of the website.  ...
docs.title: Sign-up

docs.text: When you have registered you can login to Tinkercad:   Open the  TinkerCad  website.  Click the  Login  link at the top right of the website.  Enter your  username  and  password .  Click the  Login  button.
docs.title: Sign-in

docs.text:
Create a house


In this tutorial you will use simple shapes to create a 3D house.


Login


Open the 
Tinkercad
 website and 
sign-in


Add shapes




Add a 
box
 anywhere on your workplane.




Resize
 the box to the following dimensions:




Length = 
25mm


Width = 
40mm


Height = 
30mm










Add a 
roof
 anywhere on your workplane.






Resize
 the roof to the following dimensions:




Length = 
25mm


Width = 
40mm


Height = 
20mm










Align shapes






Align
 the front of the roof with the front of the box








Align
 the center of the roof with the center of the box








Move roof up




Select the roof




Using the top grab arrow 
move
 the roof up by 
30mm








Your model is starting to look like a house already :-)


Add a door




Add a 
box
 anywhere on your workplane.


Resize
 the box to the following dimensions:


Length = 
2mm


Width = 
5mm


Height = 
10mm






Move
 the new box to the middle of the front wall. Make sure the door is 
inside
 the wall.


On the shape menu, select the 
Hole
 option.


Select
 both the wall and doors.


Group
 the wall and door. Because the door is a 
hole
 it will be subtracted from the wall. 






Get creative


Can you add your own windows, doors and to your house?
docs.title: Create a house

docs.text: In this tutorial you will use simple shapes to create a 3D house.
docs.title: Create a house

docs.text: Open the  Tinkercad  website and  sign-in
docs.title: Login

docs.text: Add a  box  anywhere on your workplane.   Resize  the box to the following dimensions:   Length =  25mm  Width =  40mm  Height =  30mm      Add a  roof  anywhere on your workplane.    Resize  the roof to the following dimensions:   Length =  25mm  Width =  40mm  Height =  20mm
docs.title: Add shapes

docs.text: Align  the front of the roof with the front of the box     Align  the center of the roof with the center of the box
docs.title: Align shapes

docs.text: Select the roof   Using the top grab arrow  move  the roof up by  30mm     Your model is starting to look like a house already :-)
docs.title: Move roof up

docs.text: Add a  box  anywhere on your workplane.  Resize  the box to the following dimensions:  Length =  2mm  Width =  5mm  Height =  10mm    Move  the new box to the middle of the front wall. Make sure the door is  inside  the wall.  On the shape menu, select the  Hole  option.  Select  both the wall and doors.  Group  the wall and door. Because the door is a  hole  it will be subtracted from the wall.
docs.title: Add a door

docs.text: Can you add your own windows, doors and to your house?
docs.title: Get creative

docs.text:
Create a keyring


In this tutorial you will use simple shapes and text to create a personalised key ring.


Login


Open the 
Tinkercad
 website and 
sign-in


Create a simple key ring




Add a 
box
 anywhere on your workplane.




Resize
 the box to the following dimensions:




Length = 
20mm


Width = 
50mm


Height = 
5mm










Add a 
cylinder
 to the end of the box.






Resize
 the cylinder to 
5mm
 high.








Add another 
cylinder
 to the end of the box.




Resize
 the cylinder to 
10mm
 along each side.


Align
 the new cylinder to the centre of the first cylinder.




Make the new cylinder a 
hole
.








Group
 the box and the first cylinder together to make a single shape.






Group
 the new shape and the 
hole
 cylinder together to cut a hole through the first shape.








This is the simple starting point for all key rings


Decorate your key ring


You can decorate your keyring with any shapes you choose. Here are some examples:


 with your name


You can add your name to the top of the keyring.




Move the workplane
 so you can work on the top of your keyring.


Add a 
text
 shape
 to your model and type in your name.




Resize the text
 so it fits on the key ring top.






View the keyring from on top.




Reposition the text and 
group
 the keyring and the text.






Try different 
fonts
 and 
sizes
 to find a design that you like.


 with some stars


You can add some other shapes to the top of the keyring.




Move the workplane
 so you can work on the top of your keyring.


Find other shapes in the toolbox


Add a 
star
 shape
 to your model.








Resize
 the star so it fits on the key ring top.


[Copy and paste] stars and change to the size and number of points. It's OK if the stars overlap - be creative!








Group
 the key ring and the stars.








Done! 




 Get creative!


Can you come up with some creative ways to decorate your keyring?




Cut your name out instead of adding it?


Your favourite team or TV show?
docs.title: Create a keyring

docs.text: In this tutorial you will use simple shapes and text to create a personalised key ring.
docs.title: Create a keyring

docs.text: Open the  Tinkercad  website and  sign-in
docs.title: Login

docs.text: Add a  box  anywhere on your workplane.   Resize  the box to the following dimensions:   Length =  20mm  Width =  50mm  Height =  5mm      Add a  cylinder  to the end of the box.    Resize  the cylinder to  5mm  high.     Add another  cylinder  to the end of the box.   Resize  the cylinder to  10mm  along each side.  Align  the new cylinder to the centre of the first cylinder.   Make the new cylinder a  hole .     Group  the box and the first cylinder together to make a single shape.    Group  the new shape and the  hole  cylinder together to cut a hole through the first shape.     This is the simple starting point for all key rings
docs.title: Create a simple key ring

docs.text: You can decorate your keyring with any shapes you choose. Here are some examples:
docs.title: Decorate your key ring

docs.text: You can add your name to the top of the keyring.   Move the workplane  so you can work on the top of your keyring.  Add a  text  shape  to your model and type in your name.   Resize the text  so it fits on the key ring top.    View the keyring from on top.   Reposition the text and  group  the keyring and the text.    Try different  fonts  and  sizes  to find a design that you like.
docs.title: with your name

docs.text: You can add some other shapes to the top of the keyring.   Move the workplane  so you can work on the top of your keyring.  Find other shapes in the toolbox  Add a  star  shape  to your model.     Resize  the star so it fits on the key ring top.  [Copy and paste] stars and change to the size and number of points. It's OK if the stars overlap - be creative!     Group  the key ring and the stars.     Done!
docs.title: with some stars

docs.text:
Adding shapes


Many different shapes can be added to  your design.




Find the required shape in the 
Basic shapes
 menu.


Drag the shape from the menu to the workplane.


The shape will be positioned on the 
workplane
.






Different shapes




Basic shapes


Box


Cylinder


Roof


Wedge


Text
docs.title: Add shapes

docs.text: Many different shapes can be added to  your design.   Find the required shape in the  Basic shapes  menu.  Drag the shape from the menu to the workplane.  The shape will be positioned on the  workplane .
docs.title: Adding shapes

docs.text: Basic shapes  Box  Cylinder  Roof  Wedge  Text
docs.title: Different shapes

docs.text:
Add text




On the 
Basic shapes
 toolbox, scroll down to find 
Text
 shape.


Drag and drop the text shape onto the 
workplane






Change text




Select
 the text shape. 


On the shape toolbox select the 
text
 textbox.


Enter your name into the textbox.


Zoom to fit
 your new text.
docs.title: Add text

docs.text: On the  Basic shapes  toolbox, scroll down to find  Text  shape.  Drag and drop the text shape onto the  workplane
docs.title: Add text

docs.text: Select  the text shape.   On the shape toolbox select the  text  textbox.  Enter your name into the textbox.  Zoom to fit  your new text.
docs.title: Change text

docs.text:
Aligning shapes


When you have more than one shape in your workspace you might need to align them.


Shapes can be aligned in a number of different ways:




Left to right


Top to bottom


Back to front




etc






Add two shapes to your workplane.




Shift select both shapes.


Select the 
Align
 tool.




Helper controls will appear on each shape. These controls will help you to align your shapes






Select alignment guides on each shape to align your shapes in different ways.


Use the 
undo
 tool to step back to try different alignments.
docs.title: Align shapes

docs.text: When you have more than one shape in your workspace you might need to align them.  Shapes can be aligned in a number of different ways:   Left to right  Top to bottom  Back to front   etc    Add two shapes to your workplane.   Shift select both shapes.  Select the  Align  tool.   Helper controls will appear on each shape. These controls will help you to align your shapes    Select alignment guides on each shape to align your shapes in different ways.  Use the  undo  tool to step back to try different alignments.
docs.title: Aligning shapes

docs.text:
Change text fonts




Select
 the text shape. 


On the shape toolbox select the font drop down and choose a font that you like.






Resize text




Select
 the text shape. 


Using the handles on the sides and top, drag to resize the text to fit.
docs.title: Change font

docs.text: Select  the text shape.   On the shape toolbox select the font drop down and choose a font that you like.
docs.title: Change text fonts

docs.text: Select  the text shape.   Using the handles on the sides and top, drag to resize the text to fit.
docs.title: Resize text

docs.text:
Copy and paste


You can make copies of any of your shapes (including 
groups of shapes
).




Copy (CTRL+C) and paste (CTRL+V) works in most computer programs!




Copy




Select
 a shape.


Click the copy tool (or CTRL+C).




Paste


Pasting
 a shape will create a new copy.




After copying a shape click the paste tool (or CTRL+V).
docs.title: Copy and paste

docs.text: You can make copies of any of your shapes (including  groups of shapes ).   Copy (CTRL+C) and paste (CTRL+V) works in most computer programs!
docs.title: Copy and paste

docs.text: Select  a shape.  Click the copy tool (or CTRL+C).
docs.title: Copy

docs.text: Pasting  a shape will create a new copy.   After copying a shape click the paste tool (or CTRL+V).
docs.title: Paste

docs.text:
Grouping shapes


Shapes can be grouped together to make more complicated shapes and models.


Combing shapes




Select
 the shapes you want to combine.


Click the Group icon (or CTRL+G) to join the shapes together.






Subtracting shapes




Select
 the shapes you want to subtract.


Select the 
hole
 tools so this shape will be removed from another shape.


Select the 
hole
 and the main shape.


Click the Group icon (or CTRL+G) to subtract the 
hole
 from the main shape.
docs.title: Group shapes

docs.text: Shapes can be grouped together to make more complicated shapes and models.
docs.title: Grouping shapes

docs.text: Select  the shapes you want to combine.  Click the Group icon (or CTRL+G) to join the shapes together.
docs.title: Combing shapes

docs.text: Select  the shapes you want to subtract.  Select the  hole  tools so this shape will be removed from another shape.  Select the  hole  and the main shape.  Click the Group icon (or CTRL+G) to subtract the  hole  from the main shape.
docs.title: Subtracting shapes

docs.text:
Moving shapes


After dropping your shape on to the workplane you can move it to a different location using the move tool.


Shapes can be moved in a number of different directions:




Left and right (x-axis)


Forwards and backwards (y-axis)


Up and down (z-axis)




Arrow keys




Add a shape
 to your workplane.


Select the shape.


Use the arrow keys to move the shape


Up / down arrow - to move the shape forwards and backwards.


Left / right arrow - to move the shape left and right.


CTRL + up/down arrow - to move the shape up and down.










Click and drag




Add a shape
 to your workplane.


Select the shape.


Click and drag the shape.


Use the arrow handle to move the shape up and down.


Type a value into the dimension box if needed.
docs.title: Move shapes

docs.text: After dropping your shape on to the workplane you can move it to a different location using the move tool.  Shapes can be moved in a number of different directions:   Left and right (x-axis)  Forwards and backwards (y-axis)  Up and down (z-axis)
docs.title: Moving shapes

docs.text: Add a shape  to your workplane.  Select the shape.  Use the arrow keys to move the shape  Up / down arrow - to move the shape forwards and backwards.  Left / right arrow - to move the shape left and right.  CTRL + up/down arrow - to move the shape up and down.
docs.title: Arrow keys

docs.text: Add a shape  to your workplane.  Select the shape.  Click and drag the shape.  Use the arrow handle to move the shape up and down.  Type a value into the dimension box if needed.
docs.title: Click and drag

docs.text:
Move the workplane


When you 
add shapes
 to your deisgn they will always be placed on the workplane.


If you want to place shapes somewhere different, you can move the work plane




Drag the workplance icon onto any surface on any shape - the workplane will be moved to match the face and change color. 






Adding shapes to the workplane




Any new shapes will be 
land
 on the workplane.
docs.title: Move workplane

docs.text: When you  add shapes  to your deisgn they will always be placed on the workplane.  If you want to place shapes somewhere different, you can move the work plane   Drag the workplance icon onto any surface on any shape - the workplane will be moved to match the face and change color.
docs.title: Move the workplane

docs.text: Any new shapes will be  land  on the workplane.
docs.title: Adding shapes to the workplane

docs.text:
Rotating and panning


When you want to change the way that you are looking at your design you'll need to use the 
rotate
 or 
pan
 commands.


Rotate


When you want to see a different side of your design use the rotate option. There are various different ways to rotate your design:




TODO: Use the view cube.


TODO: Mouse click + drag.




Pan


When you want to see a different part of your design, but don't want to 
rotate
 you can use the 
Pan
 command. There are various different ways to pan your design:




TODO: Use the pan command.


TODO: Mouse click + drag.
docs.title: Rotate and pan

docs.text: When you want to change the way that you are looking at your design you'll need to use the  rotate  or  pan  commands.
docs.title: Rotating and panning

docs.text: When you want to see a different side of your design use the rotate option. There are various different ways to rotate your design:   TODO: Use the view cube.  TODO: Mouse click + drag.
docs.title: Rotate

docs.text: When you want to see a different part of your design, but don't want to  rotate  you can use the  Pan  command. There are various different ways to pan your design:   TODO: Use the pan command.  TODO: Mouse click + drag.
docs.title: Pan

docs.text:
Resizing shapes


Shapes can be resized in three ways:


Resizing with shape menu




Select an object; the shape menu will appear.


Select the dimension you want to edit.


Enter the required value and hit the [Enter] key.


The shape will change size on screen.






Resizing wth shape handles




Select an object; the handles will appear.


Select a handle beside a side or point with the dimension you want to change.


Select a dimension to change.


Enter the required value and hit the [Enter] key.


The shape will change size on screen.






Resizing by dragging




Select an object; the handles will appear.


Select a handle beside a side or point with the dimension you want to change.


Select a dimension to change.


Enter the required value and hit the [Enter] key.


The shape will change size on screen.
docs.title: Resize shapes

docs.text: Shapes can be resized in three ways:
docs.title: Resizing shapes

docs.text: Select an object; the shape menu will appear.  Select the dimension you want to edit.  Enter the required value and hit the [Enter] key.  The shape will change size on screen.
docs.title: Resizing with shape menu

docs.text: Select an object; the handles will appear.  Select a handle beside a side or point with the dimension you want to change.  Select a dimension to change.  Enter the required value and hit the [Enter] key.  The shape will change size on screen.
docs.title: Resizing wth shape handles

docs.text: Select an object; the handles will appear.  Select a handle beside a side or point with the dimension you want to change.  Select a dimension to change.  Enter the required value and hit the [Enter] key.  The shape will change size on screen.
docs.title: Resizing by dragging

docs.text:
Selecting shapes


Many shapes can be selected at one time.


SHIFT + selecting


To select more than one shape either hold the SHIFT key and click each shape.  




Click + drag selecting


Click + drag and select the shapes you want. All the shapes in the selection rectangle will be selected.
docs.title: Select shapes

docs.text: Many shapes can be selected at one time.
docs.title: Selecting shapes

docs.text: To select more than one shape either hold the SHIFT key and click each shape.
docs.title: SHIFT + selecting

docs.text: Click + drag and select the shapes you want. All the shapes in the selection rectangle will be selected.
docs.title: Click + drag selecting

docs.text:
Zooming in and out


When you want to change the size of your design in the view space you will need to 
zoom in
 or 
zoom out
.


Zoom in


When you want to view your design a bit closer you'll need to 
zoom in
. When you zoom in you will see more details, but you might not see everything at once.


Zoom out


When you want to view more of your design you'll need to 
zoom out
. When you zoom out you will see less of your designs details, but you will see more design at one time. 


Fit all in view


You can use the 
Fit all in view
 command to automatically zoom in or out to fit your whole model on the screen.
docs.title: Zoom in / out

docs.text: When you want to change the size of your design in the view space you will need to  zoom in  or  zoom out .
docs.title: Zooming in and out

docs.text: When you want to view your design a bit closer you'll need to  zoom in . When you zoom in you will see more details, but you might not see everything at once.
docs.title: Zoom in

docs.text: When you want to view more of your design you'll need to  zoom out . When you zoom out you will see less of your designs details, but you will see more design at one time.
docs.title: Zoom out

docs.text: You can use the  Fit all in view  command to automatically zoom in or out to fit your whole model on the screen.
docs.title: Fit all in view

docs.text:
Volunteer


Our code club, and indeed all code clubs always need volunteers. 


So, if you want to help please step up :-)
docs.title: Volunteer

docs.text: Our code club, and indeed all code clubs always need volunteers.   So, if you want to help please step up :-)
docs.title: Volunteer
